course.title: jQuery Tutorial
course.description: Learn jQuery from basic to advanced with examples, exercises, and references.

jquery-intro.title: jQuery Intro
jquery-intro.description: Introduction to jQuery and its purpose in simplifying JavaScript programming.

sections.title: Introduction
content: The purpose of jQuery is to make it much easier to use JavaScript on your website.

sections.title: What You Should Already Know
content: HTML
CSS
JavaScript

sections.title: What is jQuery?
content: jQuery is a lightweight, 'write less, do more', JavaScript library.
It simplifies many tasks that require complex JavaScript code.
It allows developers to perform actions with a single line of code.
It simplifies AJAX calls and DOM manipulation.

sections.title: Features of jQuery
content: HTML / DOM manipulation
CSS manipulation
HTML event methods
Effects and animations
AJAX support
Utility functions

sections.title: Why jQuery?
content: Easy to learn and use
Highly extensible
Used by major companies
Large community support
Thousands of plugins available

sections.title: Companies Using jQuery
content: Google
Microsoft
IBM
Netflix

sections.title: Browser Compatibility
content: jQuery handles cross-browser issues internally
Works consistently across all major browsers

jquery-get-started.title: jQuery Get Started
jquery-get-started.description: Learn how to add jQuery to your website and start using it.

sections.title: Adding jQuery to Your Web Pages
content: You can add jQuery to your website in two ways:
1. Download the jQuery library
2. Use a CDN (Content Delivery Network)

sections.title: Downloading jQuery
content: There are two versions of jQuery available:
Production version - Minified and optimized for live websites
Development version - Uncompressed and readable, used for development and debugging
Both versions can be downloaded from https://jquery.com

sections.title: Using Local jQuery File
sections.description: Include jQuery using a local file in your project.
sections.note: The script tag should be placed inside the <head> section.

sections.title: Using jQuery CDN
sections.description: You can include jQuery from an online CDN instead of downloading it.

sections.title: Advantages of Using CDN
content: Faster loading time
Files may already be cached in user's browser
Reduced server load
Better performance using nearest server location

sections.title: Important Notes
content: Always include jQuery before your custom JavaScript file
Use production version for live websites
Use development version for debugging

jquery-syntax.title: jQuery Syntax
jquery-syntax.description: Learn how to select HTML elements and perform actions using jQuery syntax.

sections.title: jQuery Syntax Overview
content: jQuery is used to select HTML elements and perform actions on them.
The basic syntax is:
$(selector).action()

sections.title: Syntax Explanation
points: action() - Performs an action on selected elements

sections.title: Using CSS Selectors
sections.description: jQuery uses CSS selector syntax to select elements.
sections.note: If you know CSS selectors, you already know jQuery selectors.

sections.title: Document Ready Event
sections.description: The document ready event ensures that jQuery code runs only after the page is fully loaded.

sections.title: Why Use Document Ready
points: Prevents code from running before elements are loaded
Ensures images and elements are ready

sections.title: Shorter Document Ready Syntax
sections.description: A shorter version of the document ready function:

sections.title: Important Notes
points: Always use document ready before writing jQuery code
Short syntax is commonly used in real projects

jquery-selectors.title: jQuery Selectors
jquery-selectors.description: jQuery selectors are used to find and manipulate HTML elements. They are based on CSS selectors and provide powerful ways to access elements.

sections.title: Introduction
content: jQuery selectors allow you to select and manipulate HTML elements.
They are based on CSS selectors.
All jQuery selectors start with the dollar sign and parentheses: $().

sections.title: Element Selector
sections.description: Selects elements based on their tag name.

sections.title: ID Selector
sections.description: Selects an element with a specific id. IDs must be unique.

sections.title: Class Selector
sections.description: Selects all elements with a specific class name.

table.description:
Selects all

elements with class intro
Selects the first <li> of the first <ul>

sections.title: Using External JavaScript File
sections.description: jQuery code can be placed in a separate JavaScript file for better maintenance.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question:
Use the correct selector to hide all

elements.

jquery-events.title: jQuery Events
jquery-events.description: jQuery provides simple methods to respond to user interactions such as mouse actions, keyboard input, and form events.

sections.title: Introduction
content: Events are actions performed by users on a web page.
Examples include clicking, typing, hovering, and submitting forms.
jQuery simplifies handling these events using built-in methods.

sections.title: jQuery Event Syntax
sections.description: Attach an event handler to an element.

sections.title: click()
sections.description: Triggered when an element is clicked.

sections.title: dblclick()
sections.description: Triggered when an element is double-clicked.

sections.title: mouseenter()
sections.description: Triggered when the mouse enters an element.

sections.title: mouseleave()
sections.description: Triggered when the mouse leaves an element.

sections.title: mousedown()
sections.description: Triggered when a mouse button is pressed.

sections.title: mouseup()
sections.description: Triggered when a mouse button is released.

sections.title: hover()
sections.description: Combination of mouseenter() and mouseleave().
example: function(){ alert("Bye! You now leave p1!"); }

sections.title: focus()
sections.description: Triggered when an input field gets focus.

sections.title: blur()
sections.description: Triggered when an input field loses focus.

sections.title: on() Method
sections.description: Attaches one or more event handlers to elements.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question:
Use the correct event to hide all

elements when clicked.

jquery-hide-show.title: jQuery Hide / Show
jquery-hide-show.description: jQuery provides simple methods to hide, show, and toggle HTML elements with animation effects.

sections.title: Introduction
content: jQuery provides hide(), show(), and toggle() methods.
These methods can hide or display HTML elements with animation effects.
Optional parameters allow speed control and callbacks.

sections.title: hide() Method
sections.description: The hide() method hides selected elements.

sections.title: show() Method
sections.description: The show() method displays hidden elements.

sections.title: hide() with Speed
sections.description: Controls how fast the element hides.

sections.title: toggle() Method
sections.description: Toggles between hide() and show().

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question:
Use a jQuery method to hide a

element when it is clicked.

jquery-fade.title: jQuery Fade
jquery-fade.description: jQuery provides fading effects to gradually change the opacity of elements.

sections.title: Introduction
content: jQuery allows elements to fade in and out of visibility.
Fading effects are used to create smooth UI animations.
Fading works by changing the opacity of elements.

sections.title: fadeIn() Method
sections.description: Used to fade in a hidden element.

sections.title: fadeOut() Method
sections.description: Used to fade out a visible element.

sections.title: fadeToggle() Method
sections.description: Toggles between fadeIn() and fadeOut().

sections.title: fadeTo() Method
sections.description: Fades an element to a specific opacity.

table.description: Animation duration: slow, fast, or milliseconds

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use a jQuery method to fade out a <div> element.

jquery-slide.title: jQuery Slide
jquery-slide.description: jQuery provides sliding effects to smoothly show and hide elements vertically.

sections.title: Introduction
content: jQuery slide methods allow elements to slide up and down.
They are commonly used for dropdowns, menus, and panels.
Sliding effects change the height of elements smoothly.

sections.title: slideDown() Method
sections.description: Used to slide down an element.

sections.title: slideUp() Method
sections.description: Used to slide up an element.

sections.title: slideToggle() Method
sections.description: Toggles between slideUp() and slideDown().

table.description: Controls animation speed: slow, fast, or milliseconds
Function executed after the sliding effect completes

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use a jQuery method to slide up a <div> element.

jquery-animate.title: jQuery Animate
jquery-animate.description: jQuery provides the animate() method to create custom animations by manipulating CSS properties.

sections.title: Introduction
content: The animate() method allows you to create custom animations.
Animations can change position, size, opacity, and more.
Only numeric CSS properties can be animated.

sections.title: animate() Method
description: params: CSS properties to animate
speed: slow, fast, or milliseconds
callback: function executed after animation completes

sections.title: Basic Animation Example
sections.note: The element must have position set to relative, absolute, or fixed.

sections.title: Using Relative Values
sections.description: Use += or -= to animate relative to current values.

sections.title: Using Predefined Values
sections.description: You can use 'show', 'hide', or 'toggle' values.

sections.title: Queue Functionality
sections.description: Animations are executed one after another using a queue.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use the animate() method to move a <div> element 250 pixels to the right.

jquery-stop.title: jQuery Stop()
jquery-stop.description: The jQuery stop() method is used to stop animations or effects before they are finished.

sections.title: Introduction
content: The stop() method stops the currently running animation.
It works with all jQuery effects such as sliding, fading, and custom animations.
It is useful when users repeatedly trigger animations.

sections.title: stop() Method Syntax
description: stopAll (optional): Boolean value that specifies whether to clear the animation queue.
goToEnd (optional): Boolean value that specifies whether to complete the current animation immediately.
Default values for both parameters are false.

sections.title: Basic stop() Example
sections.description: Stops the current animation on the selected element.

sections.title: stop() With Parameters
description: stop(true, true) stops all queued animations and completes the current one immediately.
stop(true, false) stops all animations but does not jump to the end state.

sections.title: Why Use stop()?
points: Useful for hover or repeated click effects

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use a jQuery method to stop the animation effect of a <div> element.

jquery-chaining.title: jQuery Chaining
jquery-chaining.description: jQuery chaining allows you to run multiple methods on the same element in a single statement.

sections.title: Introduction
content: Chaining allows multiple jQuery methods to be executed on the same element.
It makes code shorter, cleaner, and more efficient.
The browser does not need to search for the same element multiple times.

sections.title: What is Method Chaining?
content: Method chaining means calling one jQuery method after another.
Each method returns the same jQuery object, allowing further actions.
It improves performance and readability.

sections.title: Basic Chaining Example
sections.description: The element changes color, slides up, and then slides down in sequence.

sections.title: Chaining with Line Breaks
content: jQuery allows line breaks for better readability.
Whitespace does not affect execution.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use jQuery chaining to change text color and slide up a paragraph.

jquery-get.title: jQuery Get
jquery-get.description: jQuery provides methods to get content and attributes from HTML elements easily.

sections.title: Introduction
content: jQuery allows easy access and manipulation of HTML elements.
It provides methods to retrieve text, HTML, and form values.
These methods are part of jQuery DOM manipulation.

sections.title: DOM Manipulation
content: DOM stands for Document Object Model.
It represents the structure of a document as objects.
jQuery simplifies accessing and modifying the DOM.

sections.title: Get Content Methods
content: text() – Gets or sets the text content of elements.
html() – Gets or sets the HTML content of elements.
val() – Gets or sets the value of form fields.

sections.title: Get Attributes
content: The attr() method is used to get the value of an attribute.
Commonly used to retrieve href, src, id, class, etc.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use a jQuery method to return the text content of a <div> element.

jquery-set.title: jQuery Set
jquery-set.description: jQuery provides methods to set or change the content and attributes of HTML elements.

sections.title: Set Content Methods
content: text() – Sets or returns the text content of selected elements.
html() – Sets or returns the HTML content of selected elements.
val() – Sets or returns the value of form fields.

sections.title: Callback Function with text() and html()
description: Callback functions allow you to use the old value before updating it.
The callback receives index and original value as parameters.
example: return "Old text: " + origText + " New text: Hello world! (index: " + i + ")";
return "Old html: " + origText + " New html: Hello world! (index: " + i + ")";

sections.title: Set Attributes Using attr()
content: The attr() method is used to set or change attributes.
It can modify single or multiple attributes.

sections.title: attr() Callback Function
description: The attr() method also supports a callback function.
It receives the index and the old attribute value.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use a jQuery method to change the text of a <div> element to "Hello World".

jquery-add.title: jQuery Add
jquery-add.description: jQuery provides easy methods to add new HTML elements and content dynamically.

sections.title: Add New HTML Content
content: append() – Inserts content at the end of selected elements.
prepend() – Inserts content at the beginning of selected elements.
after() – Inserts content after selected elements.
before() – Inserts content before selected elements.

sections.title: append() Method
sections.description: The append() method inserts content at the end of the selected elements.

sections.title: prepend() Method
sections.description: The prepend() method inserts content at the beginning of the selected elements.

sections.title: Add Multiple Elements Using append() / prepend()
description: New elements can be created using HTML, jQuery, or JavaScript.
Multiple elements can be added at once.

sections.title: after() and before() Methods
description: after() inserts content after selected elements.
before() inserts content before selected elements.

sections.title: Add Multiple Elements Using after() / before()
Exercise
sections.question:
Use a jQuery method to insert the text "YES!" at the end of a

element.

jquery-remove.title: jQuery Remove
jquery-remove.description: jQuery provides simple methods to remove existing HTML elements and their content.

sections.title: Remove Elements / Content
content: remove() – Removes the selected element and its child elements.
empty() – Removes only the child elements of the selected element.

sections.title: remove() Method
sections.description: The remove() method removes the selected element(s) including all child elements.

sections.title: empty() Method
sections.description: The empty() method removes all child elements of the selected element.

sections.title: Filter Elements to be Removed
description: The remove() method can filter elements using selectors.
You can remove elements by class or multiple classes.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use a jQuery method to remove a <div> element.

jquery-css-classes.title: jQuery CSS Classes
jquery-css-classes.description: jQuery provides easy methods to manipulate CSS classes and styles of HTML elements.

sections.title: CSS Manipulation Methods
content: addClass() – Adds one or more classes to selected elements.
removeClass() – Removes one or more classes from selected elements.
toggleClass() – Toggles between adding and removing classes.
css() – Sets or returns style properties.

sections.title: addClass() Method
sections.description: Adds one or more class names to the selected elements.

sections.title: Add Multiple Classes
sections.description: Multiple classes can be added at once using space-separated values.

sections.title: removeClass() Method
sections.description: Removes one or more class names from selected elements.

sections.title: toggleClass() Method
sections.description: Adds or removes a class depending on its current state.

sections.title: css() Method
sections.description: Used to set or return CSS style properties of elements.
sections.note: The css() method is explained in detail in the next chapter.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question:
Use a jQuery method to add the "important" class to a

element.

jquery-css.title: jQuery css()
jquery-css.description: The css() method is used to set or return one or more style properties for selected elements.

sections.title: Return a CSS Property
sections.description: Used to get the value of a specified CSS property.

sections.title: Set a CSS Property
sections.description: Used to set a specific CSS property value for selected elements.

sections.title: Set Multiple CSS Properties
sections.description: Multiple CSS properties can be set using an object.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question:
Use the css() method to add a pink background color to a

element.

jquery-dimensions.title: jQuery Dimensions
jquery-dimensions.description: jQuery provides methods to work with the width and height of elements and the browser window.

sections.title: width() and height()
description: width() returns or sets the width of an element (excluding padding, border, and margin).
height() returns or sets the height of an element (excluding padding, border, and margin).

sections.title: innerWidth() and innerHeight()
description: Includes padding but excludes border and margin.

sections.title: outerWidth() and outerHeight()
description: Includes padding and border.
With true parameter, margin is also included.

sections.title: outerWidth(true) and outerHeight(true)
description: Includes padding, border, and margin.

sections.title: Document and Window Dimensions
sections.description: Used to get width and height of document and browser window.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use jQuery methods to set the height and width of a <div> to 500 pixels.

jquery-traversing.title: jQuery Traversing
jquery-traversing.description: jQuery traversing means moving through the DOM tree to find elements based on their relationship to other elements.

sections.title: What is Traversing?
content: Traversing means moving through the DOM tree.
You can move up (ancestors), down (descendants), and sideways (siblings).
Traversing helps select elements based on relationships.

sections.title: DOM Tree Explanation
content: The <div> element is the parent of <ul>.
The <ul> element is the parent of <li> elements.
The <li> elements are siblings.
The <span> and <b> elements are descendants.
Ancestors include parent, grandparent, etc.
Descendants include children and grandchildren.

sections.title: Types of Traversing
content: Traversing Up (Ancestors)
Traversing Down (Descendants)
Traversing Sideways (Siblings)

sections.title: Traversing the DOM
description: jQuery provides many methods to traverse the DOM.
Tree traversal is the most commonly used technique.
You can move up, down, or sideways from a selected element.

jquery-ancestors.title: jQuery Ancestors
jquery-ancestors.description: jQuery provides methods to traverse up the DOM tree and find ancestor elements such as parents and grandparents.

sections.title: Introduction
content: Traversing up means moving from a selected element to its ancestors.
An ancestor can be a parent, grandparent, or higher-level element.
jQuery provides multiple methods to traverse upward in the DOM.

sections.title: Traversing Up the DOM Tree
content: parent() – selects the direct parent element
parents() – selects all ancestor elements
parentsUntil() – selects ancestors between two elements

sections.title: parent() Method
description: Returns the direct parent of the selected element.
Traverses only one level up in the DOM tree.

sections.title: parents() Method
description: Returns all ancestor elements up to the <html> element.
Can be filtered using a selector.

sections.title: parentsUntil() Method
description: Returns all ancestor elements between two specified elements.
Stops traversal when the specified element is reached.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use a jQuery method to get the direct parent of a <span> element.

jquery-descendants.title: jQuery Descendants
jquery-descendants.description: jQuery provides methods to traverse down the DOM tree and find child and descendant elements.

sections.title: Introduction
content: Traversing down means moving from a selected element to its child or descendant elements.
A descendant can be a child, grandchild, or deeper nested element.
jQuery provides specific methods to traverse downward in the DOM.

sections.title: Traversing Down the DOM Tree
content: children() – selects only direct child elements
find() – selects all descendant elements

sections.title: children() Method
description: Returns all direct children of the selected element.
Traverses only one level down the DOM tree.

sections.title: find() Method
description: Returns all descendant elements of the selected element.
Traverses down through all levels of the DOM tree.

sections.title: Difference Between children() and find()
points: children() is faster for shallow traversal
find() is useful for deep DOM searching

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use a jQuery method to get all direct children of a <div> element.

jquery-siblings.title: jQuery Siblings
jquery-siblings.description: jQuery provides methods to traverse sideways in the DOM tree to find sibling elements.

sections.title: Introduction
content: Siblings are elements that share the same parent.
jQuery allows traversing sideways in the DOM tree.
These methods help select elements next to or before a given element.

sections.title: siblings() Method
sections.description: Returns all sibling elements of the selected element.

sections.title: siblings() With Filter
sections.description: Returns sibling elements that match a specific selector.

sections.title: next() Method
sections.description: Returns the next sibling element of the selected element.

sections.title: nextAll() Method
sections.description: Returns all next sibling elements of the selected element.

sections.title: nextUntil() Method
sections.description: Returns all next sibling elements between two given elements.

sections.title: prev(), prevAll(), prevUntil() Methods
description: prev() returns the previous sibling.
prevAll() returns all previous siblings.
prevUntil() returns all previous siblings between two elements.
These methods traverse backward in the DOM.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use a jQuery method to get all sibling elements of an <h2> element.

jquery-filtering.title: jQuery Filtering
jquery-filtering.description: Filtering methods allow you to narrow down selections based on position or conditions.

sections.title: Introduction
content: Filtering methods help select specific elements from a group.
They work based on position or matching conditions.
Common filtering methods include first(), last(), eq(), filter(), and not().

sections.title: first() Method
sections.description: Returns the first element in a set of matched elements.

sections.title: last() Method
sections.description: Returns the last element in a set of matched elements.

sections.title: eq() Method
sections.description: Returns the element with a specific index (index starts from 0).

sections.title: filter() Method
sections.description: Returns elements that match the given selector.

sections.title: not() Method
sections.description: Returns elements that do NOT match the given selector.

sections.title: Exercise
sections.question: Use a jQuery method to get the first <div> element in the document.

jquery-ajax-intro.title: jQuery AJAX Intro
jquery-ajax-intro.description: AJAX allows web pages to update content asynchronously by exchanging data with a server without reloading the entire page.

sections.title: What is AJAX?
content: AJAX stands for Asynchronous JavaScript and XML.
It allows web pages to load data in the background without refreshing.
AJAX improves performance and user experience.
Popular applications using AJAX include Gmail, Google Maps, and Facebook.

sections.title: jQuery AJAX Overview
content: jQuery provides built-in AJAX methods for easier server communication.
It supports loading text, HTML, XML, and JSON data.
AJAX requests can use HTTP GET and POST methods.
Data can be loaded directly into HTML elements.

sections.title: Why Use jQuery AJAX?
points: Less code compared to vanilla JavaScript

sections.title: AJAX Example
sections.description: Load external content into a web page without refreshing it.

sections.title: Upcoming jQuery AJAX Methods
content: $.load()
$.get()
$.post()
$.ajax()

jquery-load.title: jQuery Load
jquery-load.description: The jQuery load() method loads data from a server and places the returned content into the selected HTML element.

sections.title: Introduction
content: The load() method is a simple and powerful AJAX method.
It loads data from a server without refreshing the page.
The returned content is inserted into the selected element.

sections.title: Syntax
description: URL – required parameter that specifies the file to load.
data – optional parameter for sending query string data.
callback – optional function executed after loading completes.

sections.title: Basic Example
sections.description: Loads the content of a file into a div element.

sections.title: Load Specific Element
sections.description: You can load only a specific part of a file using a selector.

sections.title: Callback Function
description: The callback function runs after the load() method finishes.
It can check success or failure of the request.

jquery-get-post.title: jQuery Get / Post
jquery-get-post.description: The jQuery get() and post() methods are used to request data from a server using HTTP GET or POST requests.

sections.title: Introduction
content: AJAX allows data to be exchanged with a server without reloading the page.
jQuery provides simple methods to perform AJAX requests.
The most commonly used methods are get() and post().

sections.title: GET vs POST
content: GET requests data from a specified resource.
POST submits data to be processed to a specified resource.
GET may return cached data.
POST never caches data and is commonly used for sending data.

sections.title: jQuery $.get() Method
description: URL specifies the resource to request.
callback function executes when the request succeeds.

sections.title: jQuery $.post() Method
description: URL specifies the server file.
data sends information to the server.
callback executes after the request completes.

sections.title: Callback Explanation
points: Used to handle server responses dynamically

jquery-noconflict.title: jQuery - The noConflict()
jquery-noconflict.description: The noConflict() method releases the $ shortcut used by jQuery so that other JavaScript libraries can use it without conflicts.

sections.title: Introduction
content: jQuery uses the $ symbol as a shortcut.
Other JavaScript frameworks may also use the $ symbol.
This can cause conflicts when multiple libraries are used together.
The noConflict() method solves this problem.

sections.title: noConflict() Method
description: The noConflict() method releases control of the $ variable.
You must then use the full jQuery name instead of $.

sections.title: Using a Custom Shortcut
description: You can store jQuery in a custom variable.
This allows you to use jQuery without conflicts.

sections.title: Using $ Inside a Local Scope
description: You can safely use $ inside a function by passing it as a parameter.

sections.title: Why Use noConflict()?
points: Avoids conflicts with other JavaScript libraries
Allows multiple frameworks to work together

jquery-filters.title: jQuery Filters
jquery-filters.description: jQuery filters allow you to search and filter elements dynamically based on user input.

sections.title: Introduction
content: jQuery filters are used to search and filter elements dynamically.
They are commonly used in tables, lists, and general content searching.
Filtering is usually case-insensitive for better user experience.

sections.title: Filter Tables
description: Filter table rows based on user input.
Commonly used for search boxes.

sections.title: Filter Lists
description: Used to search through list items dynamically.
Works the same way as table filtering.

sections.title: Filter Any Element
description: You can filter any HTML content such as divs, paragraphs, or buttons.
Useful for live search and UI filtering.

sections.title: Key Points
points: Works with tables, lists, and any HTML elements
Improves user experience with live search

jquery-examples.title: jQuery Examples
jquery-examples.description: This section provides practical jQuery examples covering selectors, events, effects, DOM manipulation, traversing, AJAX, and filters.

sections.title: jQuery Selectors
sections.description: Selectors are used to find and manipulate HTML elements.

sections.title: jQuery Events
sections.description: Event methods respond to user actions.

sections.title: jQuery Hide and Show
sections.description: Used to hide and show elements dynamically.

sections.title: jQuery Fade Effects
sections.description: Fade effects change element opacity smoothly.

sections.title: jQuery Slide Effects
sections.description: Used for sliding animations.

sections.title: jQuery Animate
sections.description: Creates custom animations using CSS properties.

sections.title: jQuery Stop Animations
sections.description: Stops ongoing animations and prevents queue buildup.

sections.title: jQuery Get Content and Attributes
sections.description: Used to retrieve content and attribute values.

sections.title: jQuery Set Content and Attributes
sections.description: Used to modify content and attributes dynamically.

sections.title: jQuery Add Elements
sections.description: Used to add new elements or content to the DOM.

sections.title: jQuery Remove Elements
sections.description: Used to remove elements or their contents.

sections.title: jQuery CSS Manipulation
sections.description: Used to manipulate CSS styles dynamically.

sections.title: jQuery Dimensions
sections.description: Used to get or set element dimensions.

sections.title: jQuery Filters
sections.description: Used for live searching and filtering content.

sections.title: jQuery AJAX load()
sections.description: Loads data from a server into an element.

sections.title: jQuery AJAX get() and post()
sections.description: Used to send and receive data from a server.

jquery-editor.title: jQuery Editor
jquery-editor.description: The jQuery Online Editor allows users to write, edit, and run jQuery code directly in the browser without installing any software.

sections.title: Overview
content: Edit and run jQuery code directly in the browser.
Instant preview of output.
No installation required.
Ideal for learning and testing jQuery.

sections.title: Example Code
sections.description: Clicking on a paragraph hides it using jQuery.

sections.title: Try It Yourself
sections.description: Users can click the 'Try it Yourself' button to run and modify code interactively in the browser.

sections.title: Publish Your Code
content: Save your jQuery projects online.
Build websites using W3Schools Spaces.
Edit code directly in the browser.
No setup or installation required.

sections.title: Editor Features
features: Supports HTML, CSS, JavaScript and more

jquery-quiz.title: jQuery Quiz
jquery-quiz.description: The jQuery Quiz allows users to test their knowledge of jQuery through a multiple-choice quiz provided by W3Schools.

sections.title: Overview
content: The quiz tests your understanding of jQuery concepts.
It is designed for self-assessment.
No time limit is imposed.
The quiz is not an official certification exam.

sections.title: Start Quiz
sections.description: Users can start the quiz by clicking the 'Start the jQuery Quiz' button.
sections.note: No registration is required to attempt the quiz.

sections.title: Recommendation
content: If you are new to jQuery, it is recommended to study the jQuery Tutorial first.
The quiz is best taken after completing the tutorial.

sections.title: Certification
sections.description: Users can get officially certified by completing the jQuery course and passing the certification exam.

sections.title: Additional Information
content: Part of W3Schools learning platform
Supports self-paced learning
Works on all modern browsers

jquery-exercises.title: jQuery Exercises
jquery-exercises.description: Practice jQuery concepts with interactive exercises provided by W3Schools.

sections.title: Overview
content: jQuery exercises help users test their knowledge.
Exercises are available for each jQuery chapter.
Users fill in missing code to complete tasks.

sections.title: Start Exercises
sections.description: Users can start practicing by clicking the 'Start jQuery Exercises' button.
sections.note: No registration required to practice exercises.

sections.title: Learning Recommendation
content: Recommended to complete jQuery tutorial before attempting exercises
Exercises improve hands-on coding skills
Helps prepare for certification exams

sections.title: Certification
sections.description: Users can get certified by completing the jQuery course.

sections.title: Additional Information
content: Part of W3Schools learning platform
Supports self-paced learning
Works across all devices

jquery-syllabus.title: jQuery Syllabus
jquery-syllabus.description: A complete beginner-friendly syllabus designed to teach jQuery from basics to advanced concepts.
introduction: The jQuery tutorial is comprehensive and beginner-friendly.
Content is structured in a simple, step-by-step manner.
Continuously updated and used by millions of learners.
learning_outcomes: Handle events such as click and hover
Use AJAX for dynamic content loading

certification.title: Certified jQuery Developer
certification.description: Official certification after completing the syllabus

jquery-study-plan.title: jQuery Study Plan
introduction: The jQuery study plan helps teachers guide students step-by-step.
Study plans can be customized based on student skill levels.
Pre-built study plans save time and improve classroom organization.
Designed for structured and progressive learning.

platform.name: W3Schools Academy
platform.description: An all-in-one teaching platform for coding education.

certification.description: Final exam aligned with jQuery syllabus

jquery-certificate.title: jQuery Certificate
jquery-certificate.description: W3Schools offers an online certification program designed for students and professionals to validate their jQuery skills.

jquery-reference.title: jQuery Reference
jquery-reference.description: This section contains a complete jQuery reference documentation including selectors, methods, properties, and events.

details.purpose: Provides a complete reference of jQuery syntax and functionality
details.usage: Used for learning, reference, and implementation of jQuery

jquery-ref-selectors.title: jQuery Selectors Reference
jquery-ref-selectors.description: jQuery selectors are used to select and manipulate HTML elements. They are based on CSS selectors and extended with custom filters.

jquery-ref-events.title: jQuery Events Reference
jquery-ref-events.description: Event methods trigger or attach a function to an event handler for selected elements.

event_methods.description: Deprecated. Use on(). Attaches event handlers.
Triggers or attaches the blur event
Triggers or attaches the change event
Triggers or attaches the click event
Triggers or attaches the double-click event
Deprecated. Use on(). Attaches event handler to current or future elements
Removed in jQuery 1.9. Removes handlers added with live()
Removed in jQuery 3.0. Triggers error event
Returns the current DOM element in event bubbling
Returns optional data passed to the event
Returns the element where the handler is attached
Returns key or mouse button pressed
Attaches mouse enter and leave events

jquery-ref-effects.title: jQuery Effects Reference
jquery-ref-effects.description: jQuery provides several methods to create animation and visual effects on elements.

methods.description: Runs a custom animation on the selected elements
Removes all remaining queued functions from the selected elements
Sets a delay for all queued functions on the selected elements
Removes and executes the next function in the queue
Fades in the selected elements
Fades out the selected elements
Fades elements to a given opacity
Toggles between fadeIn() and fadeOut()
Stops and completes all queued animations
Hides the selected elements
Shows or manipulates queued functions
Shows the selected elements
Slides down (shows) the selected elements
Toggles between slideUp() and slideDown()
Slides up (hides) the selected elements
Stops the currently running animation
Toggles between hide() and show()

jquery-ref-html.title: jQuery HTML / CSS Methods
jquery-ref-html.description: These methods are used to manipulate HTML elements and CSS styles. They work with both HTML and XML documents (except html()).

methods.description: Adds one or more class names to selected elements
Inserts content after selected elements
Inserts content at the end of selected elements
Inserts HTML elements at the end of selected elements
Sets or returns attributes/values of selected elements
Inserts content before selected elements
Creates a copy of selected elements
Sets or returns one or more style properties
Removes elements while keeping data and events
Removes all child elements
Checks if elements have a specified class
Sets or returns the height of elements
Sets or returns the HTML content
Returns height including padding
Returns width including padding
Inserts HTML after selected elements
Inserts HTML before selected elements
Gets or sets offset coordinates
Returns first positioned parent element
Returns height including padding and border
Returns width including padding and border
Returns position relative to parent
Inserts content at the beginning
Inserts elements at the beginning
Sets or returns properties
Removes selected elements
Removes attributes
Removes CSS classes
Removes properties set with prop()
Replaces selected elements
Replaces content with new content
Gets or sets horizontal scroll position
Gets or sets vertical scroll position
Sets or returns text content
Adds or removes classes
Removes parent element
Gets or sets input values
Sets or returns width
Wraps elements with HTML
Wraps all elements together
Wraps inner content of elements

jquery-ref-traversing.title: jQuery Traversing Reference
jquery-ref-traversing.description: Traversing methods are used to move through the DOM tree and find or modify elements based on their relationship.

methods.description: Adds elements to the set of matched elements
Adds the previous set of elements to the current set
Deprecated. Alias for addBack()
Returns all direct children of the selected element
Returns the first ancestor that matches a selector
Returns all child nodes including text and comments
Executes a function for each matched element
Ends the most recent filtering operation
Returns the element at a specified index
Reduces the set of matched elements
Returns descendant elements
Returns the first matched element
Returns elements that contain specific child elements
Checks if elements match a selector
Returns the last matched element
Maps elements into a new set
Returns the next sibling element
Returns all next sibling elements
Returns next siblings until a condition is met
Removes elements that match a condition
Returns the first positioned parent element
Returns the direct parent element
Returns all ancestor elements
Returns ancestors up to a specified element
Returns the previous sibling element
Returns all previous sibling elements
Returns previous siblings up to a specified element
Returns all sibling elements
Reduces the set to a specified range of elements

jquery-ref-ajax.title: jQuery AJAX Reference
jquery-ref-ajax.description: AJAX is used to exchange data with a server and update parts of a web page without reloading the whole page.

methods.description: Performs an asynchronous AJAX request
Handles custom Ajax options before each request is sent
Sets default values for future AJAX requests
Creates an object that handles the transmission of AJAX data
Loads data from a server using an HTTP GET request
Loads JSON-encoded data using an HTTP GET request
Parses a JSON string and returns a JavaScript object (deprecated)
Loads and executes a JavaScript file from a server
Creates a serialized representation of an object or array
Loads data from a server using an HTTP POST request
Runs when an AJAX request completes
Runs when an AJAX request fails
Runs before an AJAX request is sent
Runs when the first AJAX request begins
Runs when all AJAX requests have completed
Runs when an AJAX request completes successfully
Loads data from a server and inserts it into an element
Encodes form elements into a string
Encodes form elements as an array of name-value pairs

jquery-ref-misc.title: jQuery Misc Reference
jquery-ref-misc.description: Miscellaneous utility methods used for data handling, iteration, and general jQuery operations.

methods.description: Attaches data to or retrieves data from selected elements
Executes a function for each matched element
Retrieves the DOM elements matched by the selector
Searches for a given element among matched elements
Releases jQuery's control of the $ variable
Creates a serialized representation of an array or object
Removes previously stored data from elements
Returns the number of elements in the jQuery object (removed in v3.0, use length instead)
Retrieves all DOM elements as a standard array

jquery_properties.title: jQuery Properties
jquery_properties.description: Properties that provide information about jQuery, animations, browser support, and selected elements.

properties.description: Removed in version 3.0. Contained the original context passed to jQuery()
Sets or returns the animation firing rate in milliseconds
Globally enables or disables all animations
Collection of properties indicating browser features or bugs (used internally by jQuery)
Returns the number of elements in the jQuery object
